IT happened again the other night. Somehow, in my sleep, I became aware of an intensifying numbness in my left side. My brain sent a warning signal and I jerked awake with a gasp. My heart pounded, my breathing quickened and my mind flooded with a familiar panic: ''Is this it? Is it happening again?''

It's been 10 years since the stroke. One minute I was sitting at the breakfast table drinking coffee and the next I lost all connection to my left hand. It was beyond numb -- as though the hand had simply vanished.

The numbness quickly spread up the arm, to my face and down the left leg, erasing all sense of connection to the rest of my body. I soon collapsed, unable to sit up or stand. A blood vessel, I later learned, had ruptured in the right side of my brain.
Fortunately, my sister was with me. She called an ambulance and I made it to the hospital.

Five hours of brain surgery saved my life; the doctors thought I might even learn to walk again, though most likely with a brace and a cane. They were less hopeful about my arm, which they believed would be useless. The surgeon suggested to my sister that I could wear it in a sling to keep it out of the way.

At the age of 30, I found myself dealing with a condition most often associated with old age, yet the helplessness made me feel like a baby. It was as though I were a child, a young woman and an old one all at once.

Rehabilitation is the most difficult thing I have ever had to face. I learned to sit up, stand and walk again; I learned to adjust to living with a body that was completely without sensation on one side. Eventually, I found that complementary forms of therapy helped me to regain my health. Visualization, swimming, qigong, meditation and Chinese medicine all played a significant role.

Despite the predictions, I now walk without a cane or a brace. My left arm and hand, though limited, are highly functional. A small amount of feeling has returned to my affected side. But perhaps the most important shift happened recently when I spent a year working for an independent living program as a peer support specialist for people with disabilities, many of which were far more profound than mine.

The people I worked with taught me to focus on living a full life with my limitations, rather than trying to appear ''normal'' in the able-bodied sense of the word. With relief, I stopped trying to hide my limp or make excuses about why I type with one hand. The acceptance of myself as I am has been as important to my recovery as my physical healing.
LIVING WITH . . . Elizabeth Yoffe, 40, is a producer with First Folio Films in Los Angeles.
